awd_titl_txt: Louis Stokes B2B Alliance: North Carolina STEM Alliance
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations (African-Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians or Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders) to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM.  

The North Carolina STEM Alliance (NCSA), led by Central Piedmont Community College, with partners Forsyth Technical Community College and Guilford Technical Community College will advance and innovate current practices initiated under the inaugural LSAMP Bridge to the Baccalaureate (B2B) project. The goal of the alliance, to increase the number of traditionally underrepresented  minority (URM) students who transfer from the two-year institutions into STEM baccalaureate degree programs, will be achieved by increasing access and opportunities for these students through targeted engagement, career exploration, and structured academic pathways, and by improving retention and student success through research-based interventions, that include proactive advising, coaching and tutoring for gateway STEM courses, curriculum alignment, faculty mentoring, academic workshops, summer bridge programs, and, research and workforce experiences.  STEM focused academics and programs are vital to the workforce need and economic competitiveness in
North Carolina and maintaining the economic health of the nation. 

Data analysis and evaluation will contribute to continuously enhancing the project activities and provide opportunities for researching
and evaluating the success of the program. The project leadership team will disseminate information about the results of the project, sharing best practices and lessons learned through participation in national and conferences, higher education networks, website, and other social media outlets. Finally, the regional nature of the partnership will allow for continued collaboration and expansion of the URM STEM focused model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Established in 2015, the North Carolina STEM Alliance (NCSA), composed of Central Piedmont Community College (lead institution), Forsyth Technical Community College (phase II) and Guilford Technical Community College (phase I & II) was established to increase the number of underrepresented minorities (URM) who enrolled, were retained, and transferred to a four-year institution with the goal of attaining a baccalaureate degree in a STEM discipline.

 Strategies, Program Objectives (PO) and Outcomes:

 Strategy 1: Student Retention and Progression

 PO1: Provide programing and support aimed to increase retention of URM students in STEM disciplines.

Outcome: STEM Coaching gave support to students. The STEM Navigators worked one-on-one with  students on their educational and career goals.  STEM Academy provided workshops aimed at improving readiness for STEM courses, increasing awareness of career opportunities, and gaining familiarity with emerging practices.


PO2: Provide early intervention and programing to potential URM STEM high school students to facilitate the transition to college.

Outcome: Alliance partners offered a STEM Prep program that prepared incoming community college students for college level courses and included hands-on experiences.

 Strategy 2: Successful Transfer of URM Students

 PO 3: Provide programing and support that incorporates evidence ? based approaches in preparing students to be successful when transferring to a four-year institution in a STEM discipline.

Outcome: Students visited colleges across North Carolina and surrounding areas in-person and virtually. Also, during STEM Academy workshops and college visits, alumni spoke about their transfer experiences.

PO 4: Foster partnerships with local employers in order to provide students with direct exposure to STEM ?related activity in the workplace

Outcome: In-person visits were conducted to various companies until safety restrictions associated with COVID-19 hampered on-site visits. However, STEM Academy workshops were regularly inclusive of minority STEM professionals that shared experiences and knowledge with students.

PO 5: Facilitate faculty professional development experiences

Outcome: STEM Coaches and faculty members collaborated to identify the most challenging course topics for students. This information was then used to create supplemental instruction sessions. Additionally, research mentors were provided guidance on engaging their assigned student groups, fundamental elements of the research process and provided opportunities to collectively share lessons learned amongst their colleagues.

 Strategy 3: High Quality Undergraduate Research Experiences

 PO 6: Facilitate the development and implementation of collaborative, STEM-focused research opportunities for URM STEM students. 

Outcome: Students were provided the opportunity to conduct research related to their STEM major by pairing them with a STEM faculty member and via participation in Summer REUs at four-year universities. Opportunities to present research projects were offered annually during a STEM Symposium and select students presented at various STEM conferences. 

Project Goal and Objectives:

The overall goal of NCSA was to increase the percentage of URM students who transfer by 50% over a baseline of 1,527.

Program Measurable Objectives (MO):

MO1:

Increase the percentage of URM STEM students in good academic standing (a semester GPA of 2.75 or higher) while diminishing the performance gap between URM STEM students and non-URM STEM students.

 MO2:

Increase the percentage of URM STEM full-time students who accumulate the appropriate number of credits in one year, while diminishing the performance gap.

 MO3:

Increase the percentage of URM STEM students successfully completing college-level math requirements within the first two years, while diminishing the performance gap.

 MO4:

Increase the percentage of URM STEM student?s fall-to-fall retention, while diminishing the performance gap.

 MO5:

 

Increase the percentage of URM STEM students who transferred within three years, while diminishing the performance gap.

 MO6:

Increase the percentage of URM STEM students who completed the AS/AE degree and transferred within three years, while diminishing the performance gap.

Summary Analysis of Outcomes:

 The overall project goal of a 50% increase in the percentage of URM students transferring was not met. However, it is important to note that a 150% increase in the percentage of URM students transferring (with AS/AE degree) was achieved. This is noteworthy because this group of students has achieved a documented milestone in their academic progress.

 Results of the data analysis indicated that the NCSA had a positive effect on Measurable Objectives 2 (% of students with 24 or more credits in first year) and 3 (% Completed College level math in first two years). However, there was not a positive effect on Measurable Objectives 1 and 4 (% of students with 2.75+ GPA in first term, and % Fall to Fall Retention).  Note that the COVID-19 pandemic likely impacted outcomes from March 2020 through September 2022.

 It is important to note that based on information provided through student surveys by the third party evaluator, the NCSA colleges ?maintained fidelity to the three strategies?. Students reported that ?the personal interactions between the students and staff was beneficial?. The third party evaluator concluded that ?the qualitative data strongly suggest the NCSA program had a positive impact on the students?.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Kandi W Deitemeyer

However, it is important to note that a 150% increase in the percentage of URM students transferring (with AS/AE degree) was achieved. However, there was not a positive effect on Measurable Objectives 1 and 4 (% of students with 2.75+ GPA in first term, and % Fall to Fall Retention). Students reported that ?the personal interactions between the students and staff was beneficial?. The third party evaluator concluded that ?the qualitative data strongly suggest the NCSA program had a positive impact on the students?.
